Graphical abstract The sulfur limit, the relationship between the sulfur added and the surface Fe atoms lost (Fe/S), and mechanism of sulfur poisoning were studied using an iron Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalyst (100 Fe/5.1 Si/2.0Cu/3.0K). The FTS reaction was carried out at 230–270°C, 1.3MPa, H2/CO=0.67–0.77 and 30–70% CO conversion using a 1-L slurry phase reactor. The used Fe catalysts were characterized by XRD, Mössbauer spectroscopy and XANES spectroscopy to understand the deactivation mechanism of the Fe based catalyst after adding up to 1ppm H2S in the feed. Co-feeding of 0.1ppm H2S in syngas for 70h caused a very small change in the activity of the Fe catalyst, but increasing the H2S level to 0.2ppm or above resulted in measurable deactivation of the Fe catalyst over a similar time period. The limit of sulfur level in the syngas feed (sensitivity) was determined to be 50ppb. The added sulfur improved the selectivities of the secondary reactions of olefins and the WGS reaction even though the rates for these declined. The addition of H2S decreased CH4 selectivity and increased C5+ selectivities of the Fe catalyst. The Fe/S ratio, which can be used to define the poisoning ability of sulfur for the iron catalyst, was quantified based on the deactivation data obtained. The Fe/S ratio strongly depended on temperature and decreased remarkably with increasing temperature. At 270°C one sulfur atom was found to eliminate ∼6 surface Fe atoms, and the ratio increased to 7.2 at 260°C and increased further to 13.5 at 230°C. The Fe/S relationship with increasing temperature is in good agreement with sulfur sorption theory. The changes in FTS and WGS rates of the Fe catalyst by sulfur were also studied. The decreases in rates of the two reactions were nearly the same. The results of XRD and Mössbauer spectroscopy indicated that the online addition of sulfur did not greatly alter the distributions of iron carbide and magnetite. Both data sets consistently suggest an adsorption mechanism, in line with the results of reaction testing. XANES results at the S K-edge further confirmed sulfur adsorption, and some sulfide and sulfate species, likely confined to the surface zone, were detected. In this study, the sulfur tolerances of the precipitated Fe and a supported Co catalyst were compared at an identical temperature (i.e., 230°C), and similar M/S ratios (13.5–15.0) were obtained. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Fe catalyst XTL Slurry phase reactor H2S Mössbauer spectroscopy XANES XRD 1 Introduction Coal- or biomass-derived syngas generally contains a number of impurities such as sulfur compounds (e.g., H2S and COS), halide compounds (e.g., NaCl and KCl), nitrogen-containing chemicals (e.g., NH3, NO x and HCN), traces of metals (e.g., Hg and Pb), and other compounds (e.g., NaHCO3, KHCO3, HCl, HF, and HBr) in addition to ash and tars [1–6]. These contaminants could behave as catalyst poisons when their concentrations in syngas reach specific limits; thus, they have the potential to significantly decrease catalyst activity and reduce catalyst life. For this reason, purification of syngas must be performed before it is introduced into the FTS reactor. From an economic perspective, gas purification is the most costly process in BTL technology, covering 65–70% of total cost [7]; identifying a potential poison's limit in syngas can significantly reduce gas purification costs by avoiding excessive gas-purification. In our most recent efforts, the effects of alkali halide and alkali bicarbonate compounds [8], ammonia [9], HCN [10], and hydrohalic acids (HX) i.e., HF, HCl, and HBr [11], on the catalytic behavior of an Fe catalyst (100Fe/5.1Si/2Cu/3K) have been extensively studied under commercially relevant FTS conditions. It was found that the tolerance levels of the catalyst to each of these poisons varied significantly. Ammonia, alkali halide and alkali bicarbonate compounds were found to be the weakest poisons to the Fe catalyst. When the level of ammonia in the syngas feed attained as high as 200ppm [9] or when the concentrations of alkali halide and alkali bicarbonate compounds were less than 40ppm [8], no significant changes in Fe catalyst performance were observed during 400–1200h of continuous testing; instead, the HX limits were determined to be low, i.e. 1–2ppm for HCl and HBr and 10ppm for HF [11], indicating that the catalyst was much more susceptible to hydrohalic acids relative to ammonia and alkali compounds. In all cases, hydrocarbon selectivity was found to change very little at, or below, the lower limits of the poison effect, and a sorption mechanism was consistent with the findings, and deemed to be responsible for the deactivation. The effect of sulfur compounds, such as H2S and COS, on Co or Fe catalyst has been more frequently reported compared to nitrogen or halide containing compounds, but less so for Co catalysts [2,12–19]. Visconti et al [18]. studied the FTS performance of Co/Al2O3 catalysts when doping with 0–2000ppm sulfur at 220°C, 2.0MPa and H2/CO=2.0 using a fixed-bed reactor. It was reported that sulfur decreased Co catalyst activity at all sulfur concentrations used but its impact on catalyst selectivity depended on sulfur level; low levels of sulfur (<100ppm) were found to have less of an effect on hydrocarbon selectivity, while high levels of sulfur (>100ppm) decreased heavier hydrocarbon selectivity. Sparks et al [17]. recently conducted a sulfur poisoning study over a Co/Al2O3 catalyst at 220°C, 2.0MPa using a 1-L continuously stirred tank reactor (CSTR). A concentration of 0.75ppm H2S in the feed was reported to be a threshold limit to obtain noticeable cobalt catalyst deactivation; moreover, COS and CS2 were found to more severely deactivate the cobalt catalyst relative to H2S and deactivation by sulfur was reported to be based on a geometric site blocking model, with one sulfur atom being reported to eliminate six Co atoms [17]. Sulfur poisoning of Fe based catalysts for the FTS or the ammonia synthesis reaction was reported at the beginning of the 1920s according to Shultz et al [12]. SO2 was found to be the most severe poison for the reduced fused iron catalyst, while H2S and ethyl mercaptan exhibited nearly the same effect [12]. All of the sulfur compounds tested (SO2, COS, and H2S) at the 10mg S/g-Fe level decreased the activity of the Fe catalyst at 2.2MPa and 240–300°C, and at the same time decreased heavier hydrocarbon selectivity; this was ascribed to the formation of sulfur-promoter compounds. Anderson et al. [20]. conducted a sulfur poisoning study over an iron catalyst by comparing the activity results under the syngas with or without H2S using a fixed-bed reactor. The tests were conducted for long time periods (i.e., 56–100 days) at a constant temperature (260°C) or a constant hydrocarbon yield (i.e., by evaluating temperatures from 260 to 390°C) after the H2S was introduced at a starting point where a steady state was first established. In the constant temperature experiment using 6.9–23mg H2S/m3 (4.8–14ppmv), it was found that 80–100% of the S remained on carbide or reduced Fe catalyst; the catalyst activity decreased linearly with increasing sulfur concentration until 75% of the activity was lost. On the other hand, carbon deposition was presumed to be a primary cause of deactivation in the experiments conducted at constant hydrocarbon yields. Sulfur was reported to change very little the Fe catalyst selectivity. In the study of sulfur and carbon deactivation of Al2O3 supported Fe, Co, Ni and Ru catalysts for the methanation reaction (conditions: 0.1MPa and 390°C) using a CSTR, 13–100ppb of H2S was reported to remarkably decrease the methanation rates of the Co/Al2O3 and Fe/Al2O3 catalysts; this was ascribed to site blocking on the catalyst surface. Each sulfur atom on the surface was reported to eliminate two surface Co or Fe atoms [16]. Bartholomew and Bowman [14]. studied the effect of 0.6–6.0ppm sulfur compounds on the activity and selectivity of unsupported and SiO2 supported Fe catalysts with or without K and B promoters using a micro fixed-bed reactor (conditions: 227°C, 0.1MPa, and H2/CO=2.0). Addition of low levels of H2S in syngas, i.e. < 2ppm, led to faster deactivation of the iron catalyst compared to higher concentrations of H2S, i.e. 5–6ppm. The authors postulated that poisoning the catalyst with low levels of H2S was due to physical blockage of metal sites by strongly adsorbed sulfur, while at the higher levels of sulfur, formation of a surface sulfide having a different structure or a multiple sulfide layer was responsible for the deactivation. The corresponding ratios of metal sites to sulfur (M/S) of 20 and less than 2–3 were determined at the low and high levels of sulfur conditions, respectively. The sulfur was not found to change the hydrocarbon distribution of the Fe catalyst in the study [14]. In addition to sulfur having been reported to deactivate the Fe catalyst, as summarized above, some studies reported an opposite effect on Fe catalysts. For example, sulfur concentrations up to 800ppm (∼1.3mg S/g-Fe) were found in some cases to promote activity of the Fe catalyst under typical FTS conditions [15,21–23]. Reducing agent and promoter were also reported to affect the impact of sulfur on Fe catalyst behavior. H2 and CO activated Fe catalysts were generally reported to tolerate different levels of sulfur, and metallic Fe was found to be more prone to form sulfide relative to iron carbide [23]. Promoters such as B, Mn and K were found to greatly improve the resistance of iron catalyst to H2S poison, possibly serving as adsorbents for sulfur [14,22,23]. According to the above review, despite a number of sulfur studies (online or offline addition) performed on iron and cobalt based FTS catalysts, the conclusions of sulfur decreasing or increasing iron catalyst activity and sulfur decreasing or changing little the heavier hydrocarbon selectivity have been shown. The mechanism of sulfur poisoning of iron catalysts for FTS, as well as the ability of sulfur to poison iron (i.e., described as the relationship between the number of metal sites (in moles) affected by each mole of sulfur), have not, to date, reached a consensus (e.g., metal/S ratio varied over a wide range of 2–20). The reason for the difference is not well understood, but it could be associated with different sulfur concentrations and/or process conditions used. Furthermore, the sensitivity of iron and cobalt based catalysts to sulfur, which can be described by an upper limit of sulfur in the feed, was not systemically studied. Finally, most of the previous sulfur effect studies on iron and cobalt FTS catalysts were performed using a fixed-bed reactor, where gradients of sulfur and reactant concentrations along the catalyst bed existed; moreover, the testing periods in most studies were relatively short (usually less than <150h). Because of the quite complicated and controversial effects of sulfur reported previously (i.e., impact on activity, selectivity, sulfur limit and Fe/S value), it is important to further study these sulfur-related issues using a CSTR reactor, such that deeper insights into the impact of sulfur on typical Fe FTS catalysts can be assessed. The FTS reaction was conducted at three different temperatures i.e. 230, 260 and 270°C by continuously co-feeding H2S for several hundred hours in order to obtain representative catalyst deactivation information resulting from the contaminant addition. This allows the effect of temperature on the impact of sulfur on Fe catalyst behavior to be examined, reports of which are lacking. The limit of H2S was determined by progressively increasing the H2S level from 100ppb to 1.0ppm. The Fe/S ratio was determined using noticeable catalyst deactivation data resulting from specific poisoning levels (i.e., 1ppm H2S) in order to minimize measurement error. To compare the ability of sulfur to poison iron and cobalt catalysts, an identical temperature, 230°C, was used. In addition, all used catalysts were characterized by XRD, Mössbauer spectroscopy, and XANES spectroscopy such that the deactivation mechanism on the Fe catalysts resulting from the co-fed sulfur could be evaluated further. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization 2.1.1 Iron catalyst preparation Details of the iron catalyst preparation can be found elsewhere [6,24]. In brief, a base Fe catalyst 100 Fe/5.1 Si was first prepared using a precipitation method. The 100 Fe/5.1 Si/3.0K/2.0Cu catalyst used in this study was prepared by sequential impregnation of an appropriate amount of K (KNO3, 99.9% purity) and Cu (Cu(NO3)2∙2.5H2O, 99.9% purity) containing solutions onto the base catalyst. Between each step, the catalyst was dried under vacuum in a rotary evaporator at 80°C and the temperature was slowly increased to 95°C. After the second impregnation/drying step, the catalyst was calcined under air flow at 350°C for 4h. The BET surface area, BJH pore volume and pore diameter are 107m2/g, 0.154cm3/g-cat and 6nm, respectively [6,8]. 2.1.2 Cobalt catalyst preparation The 0.5%Pt-25%Co/Al2O3 used in this study was prepared using a slurry phase impregnation method. The catalyst support was Sasol Catalox-150 γ-Al2O3. Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) (Alfa Aesar) was employed to make the Co precursor solution. Two impregnation steps of cobalt nitrate were applied. Between each step the catalyst was dried under vacuum in a rotary evaporator. After the last step of cobalt addition, platinum precursor solution (Tetra-amine platinum (II) nitrate) was added to the Co/Al2O3 catalyst by incipient wetness impregnation. Only after the final step was the catalyst calcined under air flow at 350°C for 4h. More detailed preparation procedures can be found elsewhere [6]. 2.1.3 XRD measurements To identify Fe carbides/oxides and, potentially, Fe-sulfur compounds formed by reaction with H2S, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the used catalysts was carried out at room temperature using a Panalytical X'Pert Diffractometer (PW-3040 PRO) operating with Cu Kα radiation (1.54Å). Before the XRD experiment, the used catalyst sample was extracted using hot o-xylene. 2.1.4 Mössbauer spectroscopy measurements of the iron catalyst Mössbauer spectroscopy measurements were conducted in transmission mode, with the 57Fe source mounted in a standard constant acceleration velocity transducer. The Fe samples in slurry form, which were collected at different times during a run or the end-of-run, were placed in a copper holder, and were mounted near the finger of a vibration-free closed-cycle refrigerator which provided temperatures as low as 20K. Structural analysis of the sample was performed by least-squares fitting of the Mössbauer spectra to a summation of hyperfine sextets. The least squares fitting procedure employed user-defined functions within the Peak Fit program. The parameters for each sextet in the fit consisted of the position, width and height of the first peak, the hyperfine magnetic field, and the quadrupole electric field. These parameters were allowed to vary freely to obtain the best fit of the experimental data. Errors in the determined percentages of Fe values are about ±3% for well-resolved spectra; in those that contain several iron oxide and carbide phases, the uncertainty increases with the complexity of the spectrum (i.e., depending on the degree of overlap and the weakness of the signal). 2.1.5 XANES measurement of used iron catalyst The electronic structure of sulfur and iron following catalyst poisoning was investigated by XANES in fluorescence mode near the S K-edge and Fe K-edge at the Soft X-ray Microcharacterization Beamline (SXRMB) at the Canadian Light Source, Inc. The used catalyst sample, after H2S poisoning in a CSTR under realistic Fischer–Tropsch synthesis conditions, was sealed in the wax product for analysis by comparison with reference compounds of interest. The spectra (in energy space) were background subtracted and normalized with a two-polynomial method with degree 1 for both the pre- and post-edge regions using the WinXAS [25] software. 2.2 Fischer–Tropsch synthesis reaction The 100Fe/5.1Si/3.0K/2.0Cu catalyst was activated in-situ using a CSTR, and the following conditions were used: 270°C, 0.1MPa, and 2.0 NL/g-cat/h CO for 24h. The catalyst poisoning study was carried out using a 1-L CSTR under the conditions: 230–270°C, 1.3MPa, 10.0 Nl/g-cat/h, and H2/CO ratio of 0.67–0.77. H2S in H2 or N2 with a concentration between 5 and 20ppm was co-fed with syngas to provide 0.1–1.0ppm H2S in the feed when the catalyst steady state was established, which usually took between 90 and 120h. To effectively compare the sensitivity of Fe and Co catalysts to poisoning by H2S, a test run with a Co based catalyst was conducted by co-feeding 0.3–1ppm H2S. Changes in CO conversion, selectivities to CH4 and C5+ (carbon atom basis), C4 olefin selectivity (100×(rate of all C4 alkenes)/(rate of all C4 alkenes+rate of all C4 alkanes)) and 1-C4 olefin selectivity (100×(rate of 1-C4 alkenes)/(rate of all C4 alkenes) as functions of time and contaminant concentration were used to evaluate the impacts of the H2S. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of H2S on an iron Fischer–Tropsch synthesis catalyst The sensitivity of the Fe–K catalyst to H2S was first tested at 260 and 270°C in two different runs. At 270°C, co-feeding 1.0ppm H2S lasted for 190h from a steady state point that was established at ca. 120h. In the test run at 260°C, two H2S concentrations, 0.3 and 1.0ppm H2S in syngas, were examined for 311h, starting from a stable CO conversion of 66%. The syngas pressure was maintained at a constant value of 1.3MPa over the entire testing period. The effect of H2S on FTS activity is shown in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1 indicates that the Fe catalyst is very sensitive to the H2S poison. Adding 0.3 or 1.0ppm H2S resulted in slow or pronounced deactivation. At 270°C, CO conversion remained at 72.8% without addition of the sulfur before 145h. After 1.0ppm H2S was introduced at this point, CO conversion declined rapidly and it was only 49.8% when the H2S gas was terminated at 311h. The percentage of the activity decrease was 31.6% in the 165h of co-feeding of the poison, which is equivalent to 4.55% of loss in CO conversion per day (Y =100×(X CO,t0 − X CO,t )/X CO,t0/(t − t 0)×24). At 260°C, the addition of 0.3ppm H2S was first performed between 167h and 311h, which led to a slow decrease in CO conversion from 67.4% to 62%. However, in a similar manner to the results at 270°C, when a higher level, i.e. 1.0ppm, of H2S was introduced at this lower temperature between 311 and 479h, rapid deactivation happened again at the lower temperature. This resulted in CO conversion being decreased further to 29%, representing a 53.7% decrease in 168h. The hydrocarbon selectivity results at different times and different H2S levels are discussed below. One of the important tasks of this study is to identify the upper limit of H2S (Fe catalyst sensitivity) in the feed gas, which is the concentration that the Fe catalyst can tolerate under industrially relevant conditions. Consequently, a temperature of 270°C was selected to investigate the limit of H2S for the Fe catalyst. The level of H2S in syngas was progressively increased with small intervals, i.e. 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5ppmv using 19 ppmv H2S in N2 gas mixture. The duration of the poisoning test was ca. 400h. The results, including activity, selectivities to CH4, C5+, CO2 and total C4 olefin and 1-C4 olefin, are presented in Fig. 2 a–d. Fig. 2a shows that cofeeding 0.1ppm H2S for 96h (120–216) led to a small drop in CO conversion from 79.7 to 78.8%. Following testing at this low level, the H2S level in the feed was gradually increased to 0.2, 0.3 and 0.5ppm at 216, 312, 392h, respectively; this resulted in a notable decrease in CO conversion at all of the H2S levels. It was seen that CO conversion decreased 1.8% (78.8–77%) during testing with 0.2ppm H2S for 98h, while the decreases in CO conversion increased remarkably to 3.2% (77–73.8%) and 12.2% (73.8–65.6%) when higher H2S levels, i.e. 0.3 and 0.5ppm, were tested for a similar time period. Thus, the deactivation rate increased significantly with increases in the H2S level. The value of the slope for each deactivation line shown in Fig. 2a became more negative (−0.0023 for 0.1ppm H2S, −0.0031 for 0.2ppm H2S, −0.0168 for 0.3ppm H2S and −0.0669 for 0.5ppm H2S) with increases in the H2S level, consistent with an increased deactivation rate. At 511h, the H2S/N2 gas mixture was switched off in order to establish a new steady state for testing at a lower temperature. Based on the above results, as shown in Figs. 1a and 2a, 0.1ppm H2S in syngas is very close to the upper limit for the Fe catalyst at 270°C. To more accurately define the value, calculation of the percentage loss in CO conversion per day at each H2S level (X =0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5 and 1.0ppm) was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . Surprisingly, the percentage loss in CO conversion per day increased linearly with increases in the H2S level;, for example, they were 0.28%, 0.57%, 1.25%, 2.24% and 4.55% as the H2S level increased over the series 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5 and finally 1.0ppm, respectively. The r-squared linear correlation coefficient (R 2) value for the regression of Y and X approaches unity (0.998), further indicating the highly linear relationship between the two parameters. In term of this good linear regression line, extrapolating the plot to zero deactivation, 50ppb H2S in the syngas feed was determined to be the upper limit for the Fe based catalyst used under the FTS conditions. The effect of sulfur on various hydrocarbon selectivities is another interesting topic that has not been widely reported. Fig. 2b–d shows the changes in the selectivities of CH4, C5+, CO2, 1-C4 olefin, 2-C4 olefin and C4 paraffin with time on stream. Before co-feeding H2S, CH4 and C5+ selectivities stabilized at 3.9% and 79.2%, respectively. Interestingly, upon introducing 0.1ppm H2S, CH4 selectivity slowly decreased and C5+ selectivity gradually increased with time. When the H2S/H2 gas mixture flow was stopped at 511h, CH4 selectivity had decreased to 3.3% and C5+ selectivity had increased to 80.7%. The decrease in CH4 selectivity during feeding 0.1–0.5ppm H2S was likely due to the competitive adsorption between sulfur and hydrogen on the iron catalyst surface (to be discussed). CO2 selectivity is defined by the WGS rate relative to the total rates of FTS and WGS. Both the WGS rate and the FTS rate declined during deactivation by sulfur (results not shown); however, the declines differed slightly so that the CO2 selectivity slightly increased (45.8–46.8%) with time. Furthermore, adding up to 0.5ppm H2S had only a slight effect on olefin and paraffin selectivities. Considering the fact that decreasing CO conversion generally lowers the WGS activity and secondary reactions of olefins for Fe and Co catalysts [26,27], the slight increases in CO2 and 2-C4 olefin selectivities (Fig. 2b–d) observed during testing of the H2S poison suggests that the added sulfur modified (e.g., improved), relatively speaking, the WGS and secondary reaction rates of olefins. In the FTS reaction on the iron catalyst, the water gas shift reaction adjusted hydrogen concentration; thus, the H2/CO ratio in the reactor is one variable responsible for altering hydrocarbon selectivity. In the absence of H2S poisoning, CO2 selectivity was observed to decrease, i.e. from 48 to 45% with decreases in CO conversion, which reduced the H2/CO ratio during FTS (Fig. 4 ). This resulted in corresponding decreases in CH4 selectivity (i.e., 3.8–2.8%, or 6.5–5.5%) and increases in C5+ selectivity (i.e., 82–84%, or 72–75%) with decreases in CO conversion (i.e., from 80 to 50%) by adjusting contact time for Fe catalysts promoted with 1.2 or 3% potassium [26]. The current CH4 and C5+ selectivity trends observed when 0.1–1.0ppm H2S were co-fed are the same as those obtained with the decreases in CO conversion, but without H2S, even though the changes are not very great (Fig. 2b). However, the cause cannot be ascribed to the adjustment of the WGS reaction instead of H2S itself. It was noted that the CO2 selectivity was enhanced during the addition of H2S (Fig. 2 b), which is different from the case with the decreases in CO conversion by adjusting contact time without sulfur addition. The increased CO2 selectivity by H2S must bring about an increased exit H2/CO ratio and thus should tend to increase CH4 selectivity with deactivation. However, the actual CH4 selectivity decreased slowly with deactivation by H2S. This firmly suggests that the added sulfur played a role in adjusting CH4 formation, probably through competitive adsorption of sulfur and hydrogen on the Fe catalyst surface. The decrease in CH4 and the increase in C5+ (corresponding to lower H2/CO usage ratio) with the deactivation consequently yielded a decreased exit H2/CO ratio trend (Fig. 4). The decreases in CH4 selectivity and increases in C5+ selectivity with the addition of H2S as shown in Fig. 2b were not observed in studies from the open literature when H2S was added online with the syngas feed. However, it was reported for an iron Fe catalyst that was pre-dosed with 800–1500ppm sulfur [22]. The authors proposed that the formation of a Fe–S compound during calcination was responsible for the selectivity change. Others have observed little changes in the selectivities to CH4 and C5+ of Fe catalysts by the online addition of H2S [14,18,20]. Some investigators have reported that sulfur decreases heavier hydrocarbon selectivity [12,18], or increases olefin and 2-olefin contents in the hydrocarbon products [22,23,28]. The discrepancies regarding the sulfur effect on hydrocarbon selectivity between this study and previous studies is not well understood. The different sulfur levels or different process conditions used could be responsible for the different selectivity results. In this study, 50ppb H2S in the syngas was found to be an upper limit at 270°C. Fischer [29] first reported an upper limit of sulfur concentration of 1–2ppm in syngas for fused Fe based FTS catalysts. Dry [30] suggested that the sulfur content of syngas should be kept lower than 20ppb for the minimization of the deactivation of iron and cobalt industrial FTS catalysts. Recently, Sparks et al [17]. reported that 0.75ppm H2S was a threshold concentration for a cobalt catalyst that led to noticeable catalyst deactivation. Thus, the H2S limit for the Fe catalyst determined in the current study is close to or slightly higher than the value proposed by Dry. The slightly higher sulfur limit determined may allow for a simplification of the syngas purification process and an improvement of the economics of the XTL process. To determine the effect of temperature on the relationship between surface Fe and sulfur atoms as discussed below, the temperature of the run (after testing 0.1–0.5ppm H2S had been completed at a time on-stream of 511h) was decreased to 230°C, and CO conversion was adjusted to about 42% between 511 and 577h as a new steady state. A concentration of 1.0ppm H2S was subsequently added at 577h and maintained at that level for another 216h. The change in CO conversion with time is shown in Fig. 5 . It was observed that CO conversion decreased from 42 to 28.7% when 1.0ppm H2S was suspended at 793h. Thus, the mean percentage of loss in CO conversion per day was 3.53%. The selectivities to various species in the deactivation period were similar to the results shown in Fig. 2. For the sake of brevity, the selectivity results are not included. 3.2 Determination of the relationship between surface iron and sulfur (Fe/S) An adsorptive (e.g., site blocking) deactivation mechanism was proposed to be primarily responsible for H2S poisoning of the Fe catalyst based on the reaction results as discussed above and the results of XRD, Mössbauer spectroscopy, and XANES results as discussed below (Section 3.4). Assuming that all sulfur that was introduced was taken up by the Fe catalyst surface, and assuming that surface iron (e.g., iron carbide) sites were responsible for catalyst activity, the relationship between the amount of surface iron atoms lost during deactivation and the amount of sulfur atom introduced (Fe/S) at each temperature could be estimated. As such, the impact of temperature on the Fe/S ratio over the Fe catalyst could also be determined. Since the surface active sites of the iron phases are assumed to be responsible for the disappearance rate of CO, the percentage losses in surface Fe active sites must be proportional to the percentage decrease in the CO rate. The number of surface iron atoms per gram of catalyst was estimated using the catalyst surface area and the Fe catalyst density of 9.4×10−20 m2/Fe [29]. To avoid large experimental errors occurring when calculating Fe/S ratios, only the pronounced deactivation rates resulting from the high H2S level of 1.0ppm were used to determine the Fe/S ratio. The Fe/S ratios at 270, 260 and 230°C are shown in Fig. 6 . Fig. 6 demonstrates that the surface Fe atoms lost and the corresponding sulfur atoms introduced exhibit good linear relationships at each temperature, as indicated by the high correlation coefficients (R 2 >0.96). Interestingly, the Fe/S ratios determined by the slopes of the lines increased with decreases in temperatures, i.e. 13.5 at 230°C, 7.2 at 260°C and 5.9 at 270°C, which suggests that the sulfur poisoning strength was weakened at higher temperatures. The results in turn suggest that the proposed adsorption and site blocking mechanism very likely accounted for the observed deactivation. Bartholomew and Bowman [14]. studied the Fe/S ratios on SiO2 supported Fe FTS catalysts at 227°C and atmospheric pressure using 0.5–6ppm H2S. They reported that the Fe/S ratio was in the range of 10–20 in the low range of sulfur concentration, i.e. 0.5–2.0ppm. The Fe/S ratio obtained in this study at 230°C, 13.5, apparently falls into the range reported by Bartholomew et al. In a methanation reaction study over supported Fe, Co, Ni catalysts [16], it was reported that 0.013–0.1ppm sulfur was found to deactivate the Fe catalyst tested at a higher temperature of 390°C based on a metal/S ratio of 2.0. The low Fe/S ratio reported at this high temperature was indeed in line with the results achieved in this study, i.e., the ability of sulfur to poison the catalyst was lower at higher temperature. The changes in the Fe/S ratio with temperature based on the results of this study, as well as those from the open literature, are summarized in Fig. 7 . 3.3 XRD results of used Fe catalysts To understand the deactivation mechanism by sulfur in this study, XRD results of the used catalysts that were exposed to 1.0ppm H2S at 270°C and 260°C, as well as clean conditions (i.e., no H2S) are provided in Fig. 8 . Fe3O4 and Fe5C2 phases were detected at 2θ of 30°, 35.5° and 40°, 42.6°, 45.0° and 50.5° respectively, which were also observed on the Fe catalysts exposed to ammonia [9]. Iron-–sulfur compounds with sufficient long range order were not detected by XRD, and the distributions of iron carbides and magnetite did not change significantly after sulfur poisoning. These results indicate that the interaction between Fe and S was on the scale of short range order; thus, the accelerated deactivation of the Fe catalyst with co-fed sulfur was presumed to be due to sulfur blocking of active sites (e.g., Fe carbide). This proposed deactivation mechanism is consistent with the results of Mössbauer spectroscopy discussed below and can explain the unchanged hydrocarbon selectivities (i.e., taking into consideration the CO conversion effect on selectivity) obtained during testing of various levels of H2S. These conclusions are in line with the literature, which focused on investigating 0.5–6.0ppm H2S on Co/SiO2 and Fe/SiO2 catalysts [14], and in which the site blocking by sulfur was reported to be a predominant deactivation mechanism at sulfur levels less than 2.0ppm. 3.4 Mössbauer spectroscopy results Mössbauer spectra of the four Fe samples collected at the end of runs without and with 1ppm H2S conditions at 270 and 260°C are shown in Fig. 9 . Three phases of iron, i.e. χ-Fe5C2, έ-carbide, and magnetite (Fe3O4), were detected in all samples, which are represented by three blue sextets, two green sextets and one red sextet, respectively. Interestingly, the intensity of three iron phases in the Fe samples at the end of run – either with or without sulfur poisoning with 1ppm H2S at 270°C – are quite similar; the composition was 42–47% magnetite, 15% έ-Fe2.2C and 39% and χ-Fe5C2 (Table 1 ). However, at 260°C the intensity of red lines and blue lines decreased and that of the green line increased significantly (Fig. 9). As shown in Table 1, the amounts of magnetite and χ-Fe5C2 at 260°​C decreased to 29% and 32%, respectively, and the amount of έ-Fe2.2C increased to 32%. The results of Mössbauer spectroscopy reflect three important aspects about the behavior of sulfur: (1) χ-Fe5C2 phases were unstable at low temperature conditions, and a fraction of them converted to έ-Fe2.2C; (2) the formation of bulk Fe-S compounds as a deactivation mechanism in the current context was ruled out, consistent with the results of XRD; (3) co-feeding sulfur for several hundreds of hours did not alter the distribution of the iron phase, indicating that sulfur adsorbed on iron sites in a uniform manner. έ-Fe2.2C and χ-Fe5C2 exhibited better stability at low and high temperatures, respectively, which is consistent with our earlier study [9] and that of a study in the open literature [31]. The lower amounts of iron magnetite found in the used sample at 260°C relative to the one at 270°C could be ascribed to a lower extent of oxidation of χ-Fe5C2 by water (3Fe5C2 +32H2O=5Fe3O4 +6CO2 +32H2). 3.5 XANES spectroscopy results The XANES spectrum of the catalyst at the Fe K-edge is shown in Fig. 10 . The lower energy XANES feature indicative of reduced Fe in Fe carbide appears as a shoulder at ∼7.112keV, and its intensity lies between that of the Fe° reference compound and that of Fe3O4 oxide, and is consistent with typical spectra of carburized Fe catalysts that contain a fraction of residual Fe3O4. The feature for Fe in a higher oxidation state is characterized by the white line intensity, and once again, the catalyst white line intensity is between that of the Fe° reference and Fe3O4. Fully carburized references, not shown, typically exhibit a broad low intensity white line. Because sulfur poisoning was confined to the surface and the catalyst contains significant Fe content, no obvious features associated with S poisoning were observed at the Fe K-edge. However, analysis at the S K-edge, as shown in Fig. 10, reveals that S is indeed present on the catalyst following H2S poisoning. At least three pronounced features in XANES were detected, including two low energy features between ∼2.47 and 2.473keV, and a higher energy peak at 2.477 and 2.484keV. By comparison with the reference spectra for Fe sulfides, as well as Fe and K sulfates, the low energy features are likely associated with surface Fe sulfide species, presumably adsorbed on the reduced Fe carbidic phase. The higher energy feature resembles that of a sulfate surface complex (or related compound). It is likely associated with S adsorption on the oxidic Fe phase and/or the promoter (i.e., K, Cu, or both). Because the technique is not confined to the surface (i.e., it averages over surface, subsurface, and bulk), and because no significant changes in Fe electronic structure were detected by XANES at the Fe K-edge, the results suggest that bulk Fe-S compounds did not form to a significant extent. This is in agreement with results from XRD and Mössbauer spectroscopy. No Fe-S compounds with sufficient long range order were observed by XRD. However, XANES is not limited by long range order. Thus, the S species detected by XANES at the S K-edge were likely confined to the surface zone, and could be responsible for site blocking of Fe on the surface of the catalyst. 3.6 Effect of H2S on the FTS and WGS rates Table 2 summarizes the FTS and WGS rates and their loss percentages during co-feeding of 1ppm H2S at 260 and 270°C. For a comparison, the WGS rates, FTS rates and the ratios of loss percentage of the WGS rate to that of the FTS rate for the Fe catalyst poisoned by halogen ions (F, Cl and Br) are also listed in Table 2. Interestingly, The ratios of loss percentage of the WGS rate to that of FTS in all sulfur test runs are close to 1.0 (1.1), but in the case of halogen ions (F, Cl and Br), the ratios of loss percentage of the WGS rate to that of FTS all increased to 1.42–1.86, which means a greater impact on the WGS rate than the FTS rate by the halogen ions. The results suggest that poisoning of iron FTS catalysts by sulfur and halogen ions is quite complicated. The current results indicate that the sulfur effect on the changes in the rates of FTS and WGS differed from that of the effect of halogen ions, even though adsorption was assumed to be the deactivation mechanism in both cases. It could be that sulfur adsorbed in a more uniform manner on FTS and WGS sites than the halides, resulting in the ratio being closer to unity. Additional studies are needed to further elucidate the complicated issue of how the poisons impact the relative FTS and WGS rates of the Fe catalysts. 3.7 Comparison of the effect of H2S on Co and Fe catalysts The effects of sulfur on Fe and Co based catalysts has been studied by many investigators; however, the issue as to which catalyst is more sensitive to poisoning by sulfur is not well defined. To shed light on this, a test run with a 0.5%Pt-25%Co/Al2O3 was conducted at 220 and 230°C and 2.0MPa, such that sulfur poisoning could be compared at the same temperature (i.e., 230°C). The change in CO conversion with time, as well as the effect of temperature, under steady state conditions and co-feeding 1ppm sulfur, are summarized in Fig. 11 . In two separate tests (220 and 230°C), steady state was established for 100h prior to addition of 0.3–1.0ppm H2S for several hundreds of hours. It was found that the cobalt catalyst displayed distinctive deactivation at 220°C when 0.3ppm H2S in feed was used, where CO conversion decreased by 14.8% in 118h. This means that the average percentage of loss in CO conversion per day was 6.3%. Increasing the H2S level to 1.0ppm at 230°C markedly increased the catalyst deactivation rate, with the loss in CO conversion points being 18.6% within 73.4h which was a higher mean percentage of loss in CO conversion per day, 12.4%. Based on the sulfur deactivation data at 220 and 230°C, the relationship between the surface cobalt atoms and moles of sulfur entering the reactor was determined and plotted in Fig. 12 . The Co/S ratio was calculated to be 31.1 and 15.0 at 220 and 230°C, respectively. Comparing the Fe/S ratio and Co/S ratio obtained at 230°C, the sulfur poisoning of cobalt and iron appear to be similar, or perhaps slightly higher with cobalt. However, the Fe catalyst may be more sensitive to sulfur than cobalt since the threshold of H2S for the Fe catalyst was found to be lower. The Co/S ratio at 220°C was determined to be 31 in this study (Fig. 12), which is significantly greater than the value of 6.0 reported previously [17]. It is speculated that the different results could be due to the cobalt catalyst having been partially deactivated (e.g., by oxidation) before measuring the sulfur effect in the previous study. That is, the most sensitive sites (i.e., the higher energy sites) may have already been suppressed prior to sulfur poisoning in the previous study. 4 Conclusions The effects of H2S on the activity and selectivity of a 100 Fe/5.1 Si/2Cu/3K catalyst were studied using a 1L CSTR at 230–270°C, H2/CO=0.67–0.77, 1.3MPa and CO conversion levels in the range of 30–80%. The freshly activated and used Fe catalysts were characterized by XRD, Mössbauer spectroscopy, and XANES spectroscopy to shed light on the mechanism of poisoning of the Fe catalyst during co-feeding of H2S for several hundreds of hours. The sensitivity of 100 Fe/5.1 Si/2Cu/3K catalyst to the H2S poison and the impact of sulfur on Fe catalyst sites were defined by the sulfur limit and the Fe/S ratio, respectively, which were quantified. The characterization results highlighted a deactivation mechanism involving the adsorption of sulfur, in line with the FTS reaction results. Continuous co-feeding of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5 or 1.0ppm H2S in the syngas to the CSTR for 72–150h resulted in different deactivation rates (DR). Adding 0.1ppm H2S for 72h led to a small deactivation, for example, the DR based on average percentage loss in CO rate per day at 270°C was 0.28%; increasing the H2S level from 0.2 to 1.0ppm linearly increased the DR from 0.57 to 4.6%. The H2S limit for the iron catalyst at which nearly zero deactivation rate can be achieved was determined to be 50ppb. The co-feeding of different levels of H2S altered the product selectivities. Adding sulfur for about 400h was found to gradually decrease CH4 selectivity and increase C5+ selectivity. The added sulfur improved the selectivities of the secondary reactions of olefins and the WGS reaction even though the rates for these declined. The Fe/S relationship and the effect of temperature on the Fe/S ratio was successfully determined. In line with sorption theory, the Fe/S ratio decreased dramatically from 13.5 to 6.0 when the temperature was increased from 230 to 270°C. The results suggest that sulfur poisoning of the Fe catalyst was exacerbated at lower temperatures. Sulfur resulted in nearly the same % of loss in the WGS rate and FTS rate of the iron catalyst. In contrast, the halides (F, Cl, Br) led to much higher loss% of the WGS rate relative to that of the FTS rate. It was postulated that sulfur could be adsorbed on the FTS and WGS sites of the iron catalysts in a more uniform manner than the halides. The deactivation of the Fe catalyst by H2S was proposed to occur mainly through a site blocking mechanism by sulfur on iron sites. XRD, Mössbauer results, and XANES results at the Fe K-edge confirmed that no significant bulk Fe–S compounds were formed. However, analysis of XANES data at the K-edge of S suggested that S adsorbed on the surface of the Fe catalyst to form surface sulfide and sulfate species. These may be responsible for the site blocking mechanism. A comparison of the ability of H2S to poison the Fe catalyst and a typical Co catalyst was made. At 230°C, the number of metal atoms lost per mole of sulfur adsorbed was similar for the Fe and Co catalysts (13.5–15.0). coredata.dc:description: The sulfur limit, the relationship between the sulfur added and the surface Fe atoms lost (Fe/S), and mechanism of sulfur poisoning were studied using an iron Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalyst (100 Fe/5.1 Si/2.0Cu/3.0K). The FTS reaction was carried out at 230–270°C, 1.3MPa, H2/CO=0.67–0.77 and 30–70% CO conversion using a 1-L slurry phase reactor. The used Fe catalysts were characterized by XRD, Mössbauer spectroscopy and XANES spectroscopy to understand the deactivation mechanism of the Fe based catalyst after adding up to 1ppm H2S in the feed. Co-feeding of 0.1ppm H2S in syngas for 70h caused a very small change in the activity of the Fe catalyst, but increasing the H2S level to 0.2ppm or above resulted in measurable deactivation of the Fe catalyst over a similar time period. The limit of sulfur level in the syngas feed (sensitivity) was determined to be 50ppb. The added sulfur improved the selectivities of the secondary reactions of olefins and the WGS reaction even though the rates for these declined. The addition of H2S decreased CH4 selectivity and increased C5+ selectivities of the Fe catalyst. The Fe/S ratio, which can be used to define the poisoning ability of sulfur for the iron catalyst, was quantified based on the deactivation data obtained. The Fe/S ratio strongly depended on temperature and decreased remarkably with increasing temperature. At 270°C one sulfur atom was found to eliminate ∼6 surface Fe atoms, and the ratio increased to 7.2 at 260°C and increased further to 13.5 at 230°C. The Fe/S relationship with increasing temperature is in good agreement with sulfur sorption theory. The changes in FTS and WGS rates of the Fe catalyst by sulfur were also studied. The decreases in rates of the two reactions were nearly the same. The results of XRD and Mössbauer spectroscopy indicated that the online addition of sulfur did not greatly alter the distributions of iron carbide and magnetite. Both data sets consistently suggest an adsorption mechanism, in line with the results of reaction testing. XANES results at the S K-edge further confirmed sulfur adsorption, and some sulfide and sulfate species, likely confined to the surface zone, were detected. In this study, the sulfur tolerances of the precipitated Fe and a supported Co catalyst were compared at an identical temperature (i.e., 230°C), and similar M/S ratios (13.5–15.0) were obtained.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of H2S in syngas on the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis performance of a precipitated iron catalyst
